title: 115_hr5750
content: The Act may be cited as the "E-bonding for Immigration Integrity Act of 2018" and requires a bond. Prior to arriving at a US port of entry, an alien seeking admission must post a bond determined by the Secretary if they are a nonimmigrant in specified visa categories or have a visa overstay rate above 1.5%. The Secretary will establish the bond amount for each visa category within a year of the enactment of this section. The Secretary will annually review and adjust bond amounts for nonimmigrants in specified visa categories or with a visa overstay rate above 1.5%. Aliens must post the bond electronically with a qualified bonding agent. The bonding agent can release the bond upon notification from the US embassy or consulate in the alien's country. An alien may be required to post a bond if they overstayed their visa or did not return to their country of origin. If the alien changes their status to a nonimmigrant category that requires a higher bond, they may need to post an additional bond. The United States Embassy or consular office will collect necessary records for bond enforcement. This section becomes effective 120 days after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. VISA OVERSTAY RATE CATEGORIES. The Secretary will identify visa overstay rates for different categories of nonimmigrant aliens in the previous year. SEC. 4. E-BOND ENFORCEMENT FUND. SEC. 4. E-BOND ENFORCEMENT FUND. A separate account called the "E-bond Enforcement Fund" is established in the Treasury's general fund. All amounts released under section 2(e)(2) of this Act will be deposited into the Fund. These amounts will be used by the Secretary of Homeland Security to ensure compliance with the Act and administer enforcement programs. SEC. 5. REPORT. The Secretary must submit an annual report to relevant committees within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The report includes visa overstay rates for different nonimmigrant alien categories, categories with overstay rates above 1.5%, bond amounts set by the Secretary, Fund information, and any other relevant data. In this Act, "committees of appropriate jurisdiction" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The "visa overstay rate" is the ratio of nonimmigrant aliens admitted to the United States. The curr_chunk discusses the number of aliens who remained unlawfully in the United States beyond their authorized stay period. It compares this number to the total number of aliens admitted to the United States for each category during a fiscal year.
